p.s: The given scene 3 is an excerpt from the play Disgraced, Scene 3 which was written by Ayad Akhtar.
Her work discusses modern-day muslimMuslim identity and the struggle to fit into a prejudiced society.

The situation follows up a dinner, which was originally intended for the four involved friends to catch up and bond, but ended up with a rather tense atmosphere due to several conversations on sensitive topics such as religion, politics and work.

There are four (five) characters involved in this scene: Amir (the protagonist, muslimMuslim and a lawyer), Emily (his wife, Caucasian and an artist), Isaac (a friend of theirs, guest, Jewish and married to Jory), Jory (also a friend, guest, African-American and Isaac's wife).
Jory goes to search her husband for them to leave after being left alone with Amir, who she got into an argument with about something that happened in the lawfirm.
By the time Amir is already shouting in anger, because of her walking away from him.
As Jory enters the room, she catches Emily and Isaac kissing.
After being confronted, Isaac and Emily deny the incident, stating that he tried to console her.
Amir takes Emily's side, insults Jory with a defensive comment and spits into Isaac's face (like he did with Riukah, his first crush, a jewishJewish girl, in middle school).
After the couple left (and Isaac called him out by connecting AmirsAmir's behavior to his religion and referring to them as animals (l. 14)).
Amir calmly asks whether the accusations of an affair between the two of them were true.
Emily admits to that and he beats her antiluntil shesshe's bleeding.
This scene highligtshighlights the pressure on which each character is under, primarily because of dishonesty and unsaid, hidden bottles which reach the surface as the argument unfolds.

Regarding the extendextent of their anger it becomes apparent to the reader, that all four of them had previous concerns about each other and sentiments they did not communicate, but rather kept to themselves.
The scene is shaped by these strong emotions who come to light and spark an enourmous argument that disrupts both their marriages.
